text: I'd agree regarding SFA, very dissapointing game. Well, I would have thought personally, that members of staff had been progressively leaving the company, and seeing this trend, Nintendo acted upon it. Mere speculation of course.
author: Lucrei91

text: I suppose the issue arises from the question of did Nintendo selling Rare cause them to lose value, or did Rare lose it's value before Nintendo sold them off and Nintendo just saw it coming? The last console game they released before the sale was Star Fox Adventures, and while that game was GARBAGE (opinion), I don't see how Nintendo would come to the conclusion that Rare is a sinking ship from just one game, especially when they brought over ten games that sold wonderfully on the N64 and SNES.

author: Gsxrchick79

text:
Just to call you up on a couple of things (not to embarrass you, just to let you know).

Firstly, Nintendo never 'had' Square. Square were third party, they just developed for Nintendo, rather than Sega. Which made perfect sense because Sega had their own RPG in Phantasy Star.

Secondly, ever notice how Rare have become a mere shadow of their former self? Nintendo were completely in the right to sell them when they still had some value. Nintendo were laughing all the way to the bank.

author: GhostFace

text:
To bad Banjo and the Bird are no longer apart of my game collection :(
Would of loved to see a Banjo Kazooie game on the Wii instead of the X-box.  
Banjo was a Natural platforming game.  People complained it was to similar to Super Mario 64.  I owned both and had a very tough time deciding which one was better.  God those were some of the best child hood memories.
author: bruh

text:
One of Nintendo's worst decisions IMO was getting rid of Rareware and Square soft.  
Rareware made Banjo Kazooie and Tooie and a few games(Perfect dark, DK64, Conkers bad dur day)
Square Soft(now Enix) made Super Mario Rpg and Final fantasies 1-6 which were some of the best ones of the franchise (FF6 snes ftw.)
author: bruh

text: All Banjo Kazooie music has a hint of "darkness". I think Rare did a fantastic job fusing comedy and sinister undertones in Banjo Kazooie to honestly make one of the best adventure games of all time.
